Rickettsia akari str. Hartford is a species of bacteria that belongs to the genus Rickettsia, which is a group of intracellular parasitic bacteria. Rickettsia akari str. Hartford is the causative agent of rickettsialpox, a rare but potentially serious infectious disease that is transmitted to humans by the bite of the house mouse mite (Liponyssoides sanguineus).

Rickettsia akari str. Hartford is a small, obligate intracellular gram-negative bacterium that is typically rod-shaped or coccoid in morphology. It is an obligate parasite, meaning it can only replicate and survive within the cells of a host organism. In the case of Rickettsia akari str. Hartford, the primary host cells are the endothelial cells that line the blood vessels.

The bacterium is transmitted to humans through the bite of an infected house mouse mite, which can occur when people come into contact with infested rodents or their nesting sites. Once inside the human host, Rickettsia akari str. Hartford can cause a range of symptoms, including fever, headache, muscle aches, and a distinctive rash.

Rickettsialpox caused by Rickettsia akari str. Hartford is generally a self-limiting disease, but it can be severe in some cases, particularly in immunocompromised individuals. Prompt diagnosis and appropriate antibiotic treatment are important for managing the infection and preventing complications.
